name: methyl coumalate
Reason: The compound methyl coumalate consists of a coumarin structure with a methyl ester group attached to it. The basic unit to compare with can be considered as coumarin which has a melting point around 71°C. The introduction of a methoxy (-OCH3) group as an ester could potentially make the compound more polar and potentially engage in additional weak intermolecular interactions, slightly increasing its melting point. However, the presence of the ester group (methoxy) also adds steric hindrance and reduces the planarity and thus the possible intermolecular π-π stacking within the molecular crystal structure, which decreases the melting point. The combined effect of these substituents is a slight decrease in the melting point compared to coumarin. If we estimate the effect of the methoxy group to be around a -1°C shift due to its opposing effects of increasing polarity but decreasing planarity, we can predict the melting point of methyl coumalate accordingly.
